Crimes.Crime_Name: Withholding Material Facts Relating to Immigration Application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the Applicant's misrepresentation material to her admissibility under subsection 40(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act?

Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Misrepresentation of son's paternity leading to erroneous grant of citizenship
Crimes.Evaluation_Standard: Whether the misrepresentation was material and could induce an error in the administration of the Act
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Materiality of the misrepresentation regarding biological relationship
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Administrative appeal followed by judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Admission of child as Canadian citizen based on false paternity claim

Crimes.Application_Factor: Claim that sponsor was biological father

Crimes.Cause_of_Refusal: Concealment of true paternity of son

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the Applicant's misrepresentation material to her admissibility under subsection 40(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act?
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant claimed her son was the biological child of her Canadian sponsor when he was not
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Falsely claimed sponsor was biological father of child
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Misrepresentation induced error in immigration process
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Materiality of misrepresentation under IRPA s. 40(1)
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Impact of false paternity claim on admissibility determination
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found not credible due to false representation
Crimes.Application_Basis: Son admitted as citizen based on false biological relationship
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of truthful disclosure regarding paternity
Crimes.Cause_Description: False claim about son's paternity allowed bypass of normal admissibility checks
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: IAD relied on available documentation and credibility findings
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: False claim determined to be material
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Misrepresentation was material and induced error in administration
